comments:
i am totally befuddled as to how to set up a data source. 

i have a freshly installed eclipse 3.1M4, wtp-1.0M2, wtp-wst-1.0M2 etc, and a
freshly installed Tomcat 5.0, all running under windows xp. within this setting,
i have tried to install an existing web application that works fine under
"plain" eclipse and resin, and also runs fine under websphere 4. the application
runs fine, but can't access its (oracle) data sources.

my problem: i have no idea how and where to specify the data sources. i have tried
 - using the tomcat administration web application
 - (TOMCAT-INSTALL-DIR)/conf/server.xml 
 - (TOMCAT-INSTALL-DIR)/conf/Catalina/localhost/(myappname).xml
 - the server.xml that can be seen in the J2EE perspective, under Servers (along
with 3 other files), with diverse combinations of the preferences settings
"Automaticall publish before starting servers" and "Create server resources in
workspace"

what happens is 
... the tomcat administration application loses the jndi resources
after a server restart.  
... the tomcat-conf/ files seem to get overwritten 
from time to time (not exactly sure when). 
... the server-view server.xml does 
not seem to do anything. 
the debugging process is nearly impossible, as there is absolutely no 
feedback as to the reason why the configuration doesn't work; all i 
ever get is the stack trace info:

- got a NamingException when trying to fetch DataSource using jndi
'java:comp/env/jdbc/mmdb': javax.naming.NamingException: Cannot create resource
instance
javax.naming.NamingException: Cannot create resource instance
	at
org.apache.naming.factory.ResourceFactory.getObjectInstance(ResourceFactory.java:132)
	at javax.naming.spi.NamingManager.getObjectInstance(NamingManager.java:301)
	at org.apache.naming.NamingContext.lookup(NamingContext.java:791)

I imagine that this kind of problem happens to most people that try 
to deploy an application that uses JNDI database pools; so there should 
be some kind of how-to documentation for such cases, or a list of tips. 
the only thing i found was

http://www.eclipse.org/newsportal/article.php?id=1753&group=eclipse.webtools

which was quite interesting, but did not lead to success.
Not sure this is a rdb defect.

As this bug talks about problems with the config files I'm assigning to the JST server component.

Take note, this bug is very old and may or may not be a problem in WTP 1.5.

To edit the Tomcat configuration files you need to edit the copies within the Server project in your workspace. This allows you to version and control the files within WTP, and they are published out to Tomcat (possibly overwriting the existing copy, depending on your configuration options) during publish.
